Major stock indexes posted small losses Thursday, even as the Dow scored a new high and small caps got smacked. X The Nasdaq dropped 0.3%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.4%. The Dow rose as much as 0.35% early but then faded to a 0.3% loss. The small-cap Russell 2000 dived 1.1%. Volume in the stock…

Tiffany (TIF) topped third-quarter earnings and revenue forecasts, as same-stores sales made unexpected gains in the Americas and Asia-Pacific while posting a surprise dip in Europe.X Estimates: EPS to stay flat at 76 cents, with revenue up 1% to $960 million, according to Zacks Investment Research. Same-store sales are seen falling 1.3%, with the Americas down 1.3%, Europe up 4.6% and Asia-Pacific down 2.9%, according to Consensus Metrix.Results: EPS of 80 cents on revenue of $976.2 million. Same-store sales fell 1% overall, with the Americas up 1%, Europe down 3%, and Asia-Pacific up 2%.Outlook: Tiffany still sees full-year revenue growing by low single digits and EPS growing by high single digits."These latest financial results marginally exceeded our expectations, but I believe that Tiffany has the medium to long-term potential to achieve meaningful comparable store sales growth and drive higher operating margins and earnings growth," said CEO Alessandro Bogliolo in a statement.Stock: Shares fell 1.6% to 92.55 on the stock market today. The stock had been making its way through a flat base with a 97.39 buy point. Signet Jewelers (SIG), which missed revenue views earlier this month and slashed its full-year earnings guidance, slid 1.3%.IBD'S TAKE: With thousands of publicly traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? A good starting point is to regularly review screens that highlight the top-rated equities.Jewelry was once seen as immune to the effects of e-commerce as shoppers were viewed as needing to see the merchandise first hand before dropping hundreds or thousands of dollars on it.But that hasn't stopped Tiffany from trying new approaches as consumers' habits shift.Tiffany opened a cafe this month inside its flagship 5th Avenue store in Manhattan, and last month released an "Everyday Objects" line of jewelry, which include items that resemble a can, dominoes, and a ruler.And early this year, launched the Tiffany HardWear collection with pop star Lady Gaga to draw more millennials.

Tiffany & Co. (TIF) shares jumped early after the jeweler topped earnings forecasts and gave strong guidance Friday.Known for its light blue packaging, Tiffany sees 2017 earnings per share up mid-single-digit percentage over its 2016 EPS of $3.75. Analysts had expected $3.85, a 2.7% gain.Tiffany's Q4 EPS dipped 0.7% to $1.45, above views for $1.39. Revenue rose 1% to $1.23 billion, beating views for $1.22 billion. Same-store sales were flat. Analysts were expecting a 1.4% drop.Tiffany shares popped 2.7% to 92.42 on the stock market today. The stock rose to 94 soon after the opening bell, the highest since August 2015. Tiffany shares cleared a cup base on Feb. 17. They were already slightly extended from the buy point before Friday's gain."Despite macroeconomic and geopolitical challenges in the past year that we believe will continue in 2017, we strongly believe that Tiffany's strategies are sound and that we have meaningful growth opportunities," interim CEO Michael Kowalski said in a release.IBD'S TAKE: Most retailers, as Wal-Mart steps up price cuts and shoppers shift online. But this beauty retailer is thriving in stores and online.Sales at its Americas' segment fell 3% to $587 million with same-store sales down 2% on lower spending by U.S. customers and tourists.Sales have slumped at its flagship New York store, located next to Trump Tower, after President Trump's election. Some shoppers are steering clear of that location to avoid security and protesters. In January, Tiffany reported "somewhat lower" holiday sales.Asia-Pacific region sales rose 9% to $284 million on new store openings. Sales in Japan jumped 15% to $185 million with comparable store sales up 19%.European sales fell 7% to $146 million on lower spending by locals and tourists.Last week Signet Jewelers (SIG) reported quarterly earnings above views but sales fell short as same-store sales fell 4.5%.The jeweler, which owns mall-based chains such as Zale's and Kay Jewelers, also said it would close 165 to 170 stores and it invests in online platforms.Signet stock opened higher but reversed to trade down 0.9% at 68.25.RELATED:Tiffany Blames Donald Trump For Weak Holiday Sales

Retail companies can be great generators of wealth for the long investor. Yet since they can make such outstanding gains in the stock market, so too they can produce nifty opportunities for profits via short selling. As noted in this monthly column over the years, the smart short seller favors those companies that appreciate greatly in price, in the range…

The fight over the border tax has been focused entirely on the impact a 20% tax would have on big importers. Supporters insist that retailers like Wal-Mart (WMT) and Best Buy (BBY) wouldn't really be hurt, because currencies would adjust to neutralize the tax.Yet, while the predicted 25% rise in the dollar isn't certain — it could rise by somewhat less or even more — it's curious that there's been almost no attention paid to the potential impact on the one industry that's likely to bear the brunt of a currency adjustment: U.S. tourism.Tourism Economics estimates that each 10% rise in the dollar causes a 2% decrease in international visitors. On top of that, visitors may shorten their average stay and otherwise limit their spending.International travelers could find that visiting a Disney (DIS) theme park, gambling at an MGM Resorts (MGM) casino, staying at a Marriott (MAR) hotel or shopping at Tiffany (TIF) would be much more expensive.Staying at a Trump International Hotel would be more expensive too, which might influence President Trump's view that the dollar is already "too strong" and is "killing us." Just how much more expensive would depend on the extent to which reduced travel leads tourism-related industries to lower prices.Another hit would come from increased overseas travel by Americans, who would find that their dollars go much further in London, Paris, Rome and other destination spots around the world and opt against a U.S. vacation.International carriers like United Airlines (UAL) and American Airlines (AAL) may not suffer as much, since more outbound American travelers could ease the pain of fewer U.S.-bound tourists. Similarly, global hotel chains like Marriott may also see additional bookings by Americans abroad. But more domestic-focused businesses won't have such offsets.A major, unilateral increase in the U.S. currency could come at a pretty significant price. International travel added $247 billion to the U.S. economy last year and generated an $88 billion surplus, relative to what Americans spent abroad, according to the U.S. Travel Association's analysis of Commerce Department data. That's down from a $98 billion travel surplus in 2015. It's not clear how much of the narrower surplus was related to a stronger dollar, but there is generally a lag before shifts in currencies affect travel, given advance bookings.The figures include educational tourism — foreign students attending U.S. colleges and universities and generally paying much more than local residents to do so. With a 25% rise in the dollar, the U.S. might not look like quite as an attractive place to study. In 2015, education-related tourism totaled $35.8 billion."Regular exporters would, under border adjustment, receive a subsidy that would offset the exchange rate impact; but hotel owners presumably wouldn't," wrote American Enterprise Institute resident scholar Stan Veuger. "Or would U.S. taxpayers start subsidizing the vacations of Chinese tourists?"That seems as unlikely as federal government subsidies to let foreign students attend the University of California at Berkeley, he adds.While the impact on tourism has been almost entirely absent from the debate, it could play a bigger role as GOP senators decide whether they can back the House plan. Georgia Sen. David Perdue, former CEO of Dollar General (DG), has already signaled his fierce opposition, meaning just two more GOP defections could kill it.Expect Sen. Dean Heller of Nevada and Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida, who both represent top-five states for foreign travel, to come under heavy lobbying pressure from the tourism industry. Border states Texas and Arizona also are big tourism destinations, with Mexican travelers spending $19.7 billion in the U.S. in 2015.IBD'S TAKE: If the dollar appreciates 20% to 25% against foreign currencies, U.S. investors holding ADRs of foreign equities like Alibaba or international ETFs would take a hit.The projected rise in the dollar would come from already lofty levels. The U.S. dollar index, which measures the greenback against a basket of advanced-economy currencies, surged 26% from July 2014 to March 2015, hitting the highest level since 2003.On earnings calls in the fall of 2015, Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide noted "lower volumes of inbound international travelers due to the strong dollar," while Tiffany said it "continued to experience a negative effect on foreign tourists spending in the U.S."While the dollar eased off of those levels for most of 2016, it has strengthened again on expectations for a stronger U.S. economy under Trump.AEI's Veuger also points out that real estate is another "quasi-exporting" industry that might feel an impact from the border tax, since foreigners purchase some $100 billion worth of residential properties in a year, about half paid for in cash.RELATED:If Border Tax Dies, Trump Corporate Tax Cut May CollapseTreasury Might Write Checks To Boeing Under GOP Tax Reform

A yawning trench of dirt, wood and exposed cables currently sits at the mouth of the Westfield Century City in west Los Angeles. The Apple (AAPL) store is still open and the Tesla (TSLA) showroom has been moved to a different spot, but much of the shopping center remains under construction.When it reopens this year, it will have expanded into a glamorous 1.2-million-square-foot beast of a mall — 422,000 square feet larger — complete with Italian food emporium Eataly, hip burger joint Shake Shack (SHAK) and "new high-fashion streetside boutiques."XIn fact, the Century City mall won't just be a mall, it will be "an immersive sensory experience unprecedented in the modern retail space," according to a 2015 Westfield press release. This location hardly needs a tuneup. With $1,457 in sales per square foot, it is the ninth-most productive mall in the country, according to a CNBC story from May, citing real estate research firm Green Street Advisors. So why spend $800 million on a makeover?Looks matter more than ever, particularly as social-media bragging rights become an essential part of the millennial shopping experience. So these days, every retailer has to put on a good show, ramping up the drama to boost foot traffic and cheat death as Amazon (AMZN) spells doom for more and more American malls."(Young people are) very into cataloging everything they do via social media, and so these more luxury experiences have more social currency," said Talmage Advisors CEO Liz Dunn.That could mean Snapchatting from inside a Tiffany (TIF) — regardless of whether you buy something — or taking a topside photo of your artisanal lunch. (Never has flat lay photography been so popular.)"Whatever it is, there's a lot more social currency to that than saying 'I'm at a TGI Friday's,' " she said.The mall's transformation into an "immersive sensory experience" contrasts with the post-World War II bloom of malls, which attracted Americans to cookie-cutter hubs with their one-stop-shopping convenience. That has since given way to the splendid isolationism of two-day shipping via Amazon Prime, hollowing out traditional malls and forcing the survivors to become purveyors of experiences that can be shared online.Fellow L.A.-based shopping center The Grove, owned by Caruso, underscores the trend and is a social-media maven's dream.It houses many of the same stores as a regional mall does — like Banana Republic, J. Crew and Anthropologie — but also features a fountain, trolley and live music, helping put it at No. 2 on CNBC/Green Street Advisors' list with a $2,200 in sales per square foot. The photogenic plaza was even once the backdrop for Hollywood-gossip show "Extra," which has no doubt upped its social cred among tourists who want a glimpse of glam."This is where all the B-list celebs, YouTube stars, and Instagram influencers shop (I saw an Instagram male model there myself when I went)," gushed one Yelp reviewer visiting from Toronto.The lure of exclusivity, that close cousin of luxury, is another way retailers have amped up the theatrics.It's a tactic long employed by an athletic-footwear industry that routinely releases shoes in small batches, driving up demand from sneakerheads and high-schoolers alike. There's even a sneaker stock exchange, StockX, devoted to the resale of Jordans, Kobes and anything Kanye has ever designed for Adidas.Other retailers have since caught on. Coach (COH) and Disney (DIS) last year introduced a limited-edition House of Mouse-themed handbag line. Spice Girl-turned-fashion designer Victoria Beckham is behind Target's (TGT) upcoming capsule collection. And H&M seems to have an endless series of designer linkups in the pipeline.The New York Times even declared 2016 "the year of the drop," referring to the slew of limited-edition releases and pop-up shops, like Kylie Jenner's blink-and-it's-gone store, designed to create shopper frenzy.The Hollywood Reporter called the December opening of Jenner's pop-up, located within the Westfield Topanga Mall in Los Angeles' San Fernando Valley, "mayhem."Mayhem is the antithesis of convenience, when it comes to shopping. But that is the point. No one wants to stand in line outside for hours waiting for laundry detergent. A Kylie Lip Kit, however, is not long for this world.To get a teen or 20-something to the mall — and most "drop" shoppers are under 30, noted the Times — the mall must act a little more like a nightclub, velvet ropes and all.Even supermarkets are in on the action: Some Whole Foods Market (WFM), Kroger (KR) and Gelson's locations feature wine bars, a premium add-on meant to keep grocery shoppers in stores longer.Such theater may seem gimmicky, but it works, and is also being seen in actual theaters. The local cineplex, a requisite component of any shopping mall, is also undergoing a revamp.On the defensive from Netflix (NFLX) and massive TVs, theaters have been making screens bigger, audio better, and seats more spacious. And as an alternative to grabbing popcorn from the concession stand and trying to find a decent seat, more theaters now serve cocktails and dinner to your reserved Barcalounger while that summer blockbuster plays in Imax 3D.AMC (AMC), for example, embarked three years ago on a $600 million reseating project to rip out traditional chairs and replace them with recliners.AMC, which has called its collective upgrades a "winning playbook," outlined at a recent presentation that attendance has grown 53% and revenue leapt 70% in its 1,500 or so reseated theaters. It has thousands more theaters in line to be updated.Top exhibitor chain Regal Cinemas (RGC) also recently attributed recent outperformance to plush seating, calling out recliner sites as the "biggest driver.""Theaters have to do something to differentiate themselves from the in-home experience," said RBC analyst Leo Kulp. "That's really what's driven these investments over the past several years."Theaters, full-service restaurants and other bells and whistles have woven themselves into a successful mall's narrative, but it may be a while before the experiential stuff surpasses retail stores that sell shirts and shoes."The future will certainly bring less retail, but it will take a few years to tip the scale" so that retailers become a mall's minority residents, said NPD Group retail analyst Marshal Cohen.There is also some hope for once-reliable mall anchors like Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), even as Macy's reportedly considers selling itself after a brutal holiday season.The Grove has a Nordstrom, and the revamped Westfield Century City is actually adding a department store to the mix, for a total of three major names. It will now house a two-story Macy's, three-story Bloomingdale's and a three-story Nordstrom that is being relocated from the next mall over.But the massive upgrades being made to shopping arenas could even further widen the gap between top-market malls and their less-moneyed brethren.Of the more-than-1,000 malls in America, the 300 or so top-market "A-malls" account for 75% of mall value (a metric comprised of sales productivity, size and other factors), according to Green Street Advisors.So what's a midtier mall to do? For developers, the answer may be: Change or die.Strong anchors are "imperative" for a shopping center's long-term viability, according to Green Street's 2017 mall outlook report, since income-generating tenants want malls with "vibrant," traffic-driving anchors.As department stores waver, Green Street's research points to restaurants, movie theaters and "traditional power-center tenants" — like Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and pet stores — as rising power players.But Talmage Advisors' Dunn is not optimistic."The problem is, it's a little bit of a self-fulfilling prophesy," she said. "The landlords aren't willing to invest in the lower-tier centers, and the thing that would potentially take a lower-tier center to help it jump a bracket is investment. But it's hard to justify the investment if the center's performance isn't in that top-tier range."

Ah, romance! Valentine's Day is at hand. What better time to consider stocks that have romantic connotations. Financial advisors, money managers and investment strategists suggested them to IBD via email. But watch out. Several look more like broken hearts than dream dates.As for their efficacy in the romance department, we'll let you be the judge of that.Valentine's Day connection? "There's a reason the phrase 'Netflix and chill' is a phrase," Reeves said. "While perhaps not as romantic as dinner and a show, snuggling up on the couch with streaming video is a common courtship ritual in this digital age."Netflix has a perfect 99 Composite Rating from IBD. The Composite Rating, which starts at 1 and runs to 99, combines IBD's five performance ratings. Stocks poised to move higher often have a Comp Rating of 95 or higher. In Netflix's case, after six quarters of declining earnings per share growth, EPS growth has accelerated for three stanzas in a row, advancing 50%, 71% and 114%."The reasons (for Netflix's earnings rebound) were obvious," Reeves said, "as (it) crushed expectations on international subscriber growth, and posted a better-than-expected outlook for the future.""That momentum has continued in its most recent earnings report," Reeves added, "which beat on both the top and bottom lines. A continued push into original content with smash hits 'Stranger Things' and 'Narcos' coupled with aggressive overseas growth makes this a stock to love in 2017."Yepez describes a Valentine's Day meal at a Texas Roadhouse restaurant as a romantic occasion at a lovable price. For long-term investors, Yepez points to the stock's 27 consecutive quarters of same-store sales growth. "And (it) continues to take market share from other restaurant chains," he said.The company runs and franchises 483 of its namesake restaurants in 49 states. The stock has a so-so 71 Composite Rating from IBD. It is ranked only No. 10 in IBD's Retail-Restaurants industry group.The stock's strengths include four straight years of annual EPS growth, a very strong 95 EPS Rating — which puts it in the top 5% of all publicly traded companies in terms of EPS growth — and 35% average EPS growth over the three most recent quarters. EPS is expected to rise 29% this year.Etsy runs online and offline markets where people and businesses buy and sell largely handmade goods. Magoon calls Etsy the premier online site for custom jewelry, vintage goods and other crafts. Online retailers like Etsy tend to see sales surge around Valentine's Day, Magoon says.And it has a protective moat, Magoon adds. "Unlike other traditional and online retailers, Etsy's offerings are less likely to get 'Amazoned' due to their uniqueness," Magoon said.In addition, Magoon sees Etsy as a possible takeover target.After deepening losses since 2012, the company is expected to post a shallower loss of six cents a share for 2016 and post a profit of 14 cents for this year, according to Thomson Reuters First Call. Trading around 12, shares are 23% below their Oct. 7 high. The stock has a weak 40 Composite Rating.The Valentine's Day tie-in? The wholesale membership warehouse chain's wine and diamond sales, Wicker says.  Costco's jewelry pricing is competitive, Wicker adds. "And for those who need to hedge their bets, Costco has a liberal and generous return policy," he said. In addition, Costco's membership fees give its near-term cash flow visibility. Plus, operating margins should benefit from the switch to a new credit card vendor and increase in membership dues.Annual earnings growth over the past three years averaged a modest 8%. Yearly sales growth was 4% over the same period. The stock has a weak 52 Comp Rating, though its trading at its all-time high. EPS growth the past three quarters was 6%, 2% and 7%, which followed two frames of declining growth.Over the past four quarters sales have fallen by 4.6%. EPS also fell. The company has a dividend yield of 2.3% and has a dividend growth rate of 11%. But Wilsey says the company uses 47.4% of earnings to pay its dividend. Before its most recent quarterly EPS gain of 9%, EPS growth fell six quarters in a row.RELATED:Where Mutual Fund Bigwigs Expect To See Stock Gains In 2017Mutual Fund Managers Cite Tech, Financial, Energy, Industrial Names They Like For '17
